Package mz.intro.introDPQ

Interface IntroDPQ<T extends Comparable>

Type Parameters:
T - setting of a type based on which the elements can be sorted.
All Superinterfaces:
InsertionInterface<T>, Intro<T>, QuickInterface<T>, Sort<T>, SortSwap<T>
All Known Implementing Classes:
IntroDPQAnother, IntroDPQBatcherOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQBubble, IntroDPQCocktail, IntroDPQComb, IntroDPQDoubleSelection, IntroDPQDualPivotQuick, IntroDPQGnome, IntroDPQHeap, IntroDPQInsertion, IntroDPQMerge, IntroDPQMerge3, IntroDPQMergeInPlace, IntroDPQMergeInsertion, IntroDPQOddEven, IntroDPQOddEvenMerge, IntroDPQQuick, IntroDPQQuick3, IntroDPQSelection, IntroDPQShell, IntroDPQSmoothHeap, IntroDPQStableQuick, IntroDPQTernaryHeap, IntroDPQTim, IntroDPQWeakHeap, IntroDPQWeaveMerge, IntroDPQWiki
public interface IntroDPQ<T extends Comparable> extends Intro<T>
IntroDPQ (Dual Pivot Quick) Sort is a hybrid sorting algorithm that combines the strengths of Dual Pivot Quick Sort and Insertion Sort. It aims to provide fast average-case performance while maintaining worst-case guarantees. The basic idea behind Intro Sort is to start with Dual Pivot Quick Sort, which is known for its efficiency on average, but has a worst-case time complexity of O(n^2) in certain scenarios. To mitigate the risk of Dual Pivot Quick Sort's worst-case behavior, Intro Sort monitors the recursion depth during the sorting process. If the depth exceeds a certain threshold, the algorithm switches to HeapSort, which guarantees worst-case O(n log(n)) time complexity but has higher overhead. Additionally, for small subarrays, IntroSort switches to Insertion Sort, which has good performance for small input sizes.
Since:
1.0
Author:
Magyar Zolt√°n

  • Method Details

    • introRecursiveInc

      default void introRecursiveInc(T[] array, int left, int right, int maxDepth)
      introRecursiveInc that performs a recursive implementation of the intro sort algorithm.
      • It checks if the size of the sub-array (right - left) is larger than INTRO_SIZE. If it is, it proceeds with the intro sort algorithm. If not, it uses insertion sort to sort the sub-array.
      • If the maximum recursion depth maxDepth is 0, it directly uses the introSortClassInc method to sort the sub-array using a different sorting algorithm. This is a base case to prevent excessive recursion.
      • If the sub-array size is larger than INTRO_SIZE and the maximum recursion depth is not 0, it performs the following steps:
      • Calls the partitionDualInc method to partition the sub-array and obtain the pivot indices.
      • Recursively calls introRecursiveInc on the three sub-arrays:
      • From left to (pivots[0] - 1) (elements smaller than the first pivot)
      • From (pivots[0] + 1) to (pivots[1] - 1) (elements between the two pivots)
      • From (pivots[1] + 1) to right (elements greater than the second pivot)
      • The recursion depth maxDepth is decremented by 1 in each recursive call.
      • If the sub-array size is smaller or equal to INTRO_SIZE, it uses the insertionInc method to perform insertion sort on the sub-array.
      introRecursiveInc method recursively applies the intro sort algorithm to sort a given array. It switches to insertion sort when the sub-array size becomes small enough. The maximum recursion depth is used to limit the depth of recursion to prevent excessive stack usage.
      Specified by:
      introRecursiveInc in interface Intro<T extends Comparable>
      Parameters:
      array - The array to be sorted.
      left - The starting index of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The ending index (inclusive) of the subarray to be sorted.
      maxDepth - The maximum depth or recursion level allowed before switching to another sorting algorithm.
      See Also:
      • Intro.INTRO_SIZE
      • Intro.introInc(Comparable[])
      • Intro.introSortClassInc(Comparable[], int, int)
      • InsertionInterface.insertionInc(Comparable[], int, int)

    • introRecursiveDec

      default void introRecursiveDec(T[] array, int left, int right, int maxDepth)
      introRecursiveDec that performs a recursive implementation of the intro sort algorithm.
      • It checks if the size of the sub-array (right - left) is larger than INTRO_SIZE. If it is, it proceeds with the intro sort algorithm. If not, it uses insertion sort to sort the sub-array.
      • If the maximum recursion depth maxDepth is 0, it directly uses the introSortClassDec method to sort the sub-array using a different sorting algorithm. This is a base case to prevent excessive recursion.
      • If the sub-array size is larger than INTRO_SIZE and the maximum recursion depth is not 0, it performs the following steps:
      • Calls the partitionDualDec method to partition the sub-array and obtain the pivot indices.
      • Recursively calls introRecursiveDec on the three sub-arrays:
      • From left to (pivots[0] - 1) (elements smaller than the first pivot)
      • From (pivots[0] + 1) to (pivots[1] - 1) (elements between the two pivots)
      • From (pivots[1] + 1) to right (elements greater than the second pivot)
      • The recursion depth maxDepth is decremented by 1 in each recursive call.
      • If the sub-array size is smaller or equal to INTRO_SIZE, it uses the insertionDec method to perform insertion sort on the sub-array.
      introRecursiveDec method recursively applies the intro sort algorithm to sort a given array. It switches to insertion sort when the sub-array size becomes small enough. The maximum recursion depth is used to limit the depth of recursion to prevent excessive stack usage.
      Specified by:
